questions.text: A 30-year-old female presenting with an unsteady gait, forgetfulness, labile moods, and Kayser-Fleischer rings was diagnosed with Wilson’s disease. Which of the following options correctly indicates the gene mutated in this condition and its location?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ATP7B gene on chromosome 13

Explanation:

  • Wilson’s disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene located on chromosome 13.
  • The ATP7A gene on chromosome 17 is associated with Menkes disease.

Wilson’s disease

  • It is a genetic disorder caused by ATP7B gene mutations, leading to impaired copper transport and accumulation in the liver, brain, and other organs.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Kayser-Fleischer Rings: These are characteristic brownish-green rings seen in the cornea due to copper deposition and are a hallmark feature of Wilson's disease.
    • Serum copper is raised, while ceruloplasmin levels (a copper-binding protein) are decreased in Wilson's disease.
    • Increased urinary copper excretion is a characteristic finding.
  • Findings:
    • Low levels of Serum Ceruloplasmin.
    • Increased 24-hour Urinary Copper Excretion (Most specific).
    • Liver Function Tests (LFTs) may show abnormalities.
    • Kayser-Fleischer Rings Examination: Greenish-brown rings in the cornea.
    • Genetic Testing: For ATP7B gene mutations, confirming diagnosis.
    • Liver Biopsy (Gold standard): Demonstrates hepatic copper accumulation.
    • Brain Imaging: MRI to assess neurological involvement.

questions.text: A cut section of liver is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Focal nodular hyperplasia

Explanation:

A well-demarcated liver lesion with a central stellate scar on gross examination is characteristic of Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH).

  • It is a benign, non-neoplastic lesion that is most common in women. It occurs due to altered blood flow, which causes hyperplastic changes in hepatocytes.
  • Multifocal FNH can occur in
    • Hepatic or extrahepatic hemangioma
    • Vascular malformations
    • Brain tumours (meningioma, astrocytoma)
    • Histopathology
      • It is less than 5 cm in diameter, well-circumscribed, lacks a capsule, and has a central stellate scar.
      • Microscopically, fibrous septa radiating from the central scar divide the hepatic parenchyma into nodules. A large central artery is usually present.

The image shows fibrous septae dividing the parenchyma.

  • USG: It is incidentally seen on imaging.

 

A USG of the liver indicating a mass with a central stellate scar

Incorrect Options:

Hepatic adenoma (Option A): Usually solitary, lacks central scar, associated with oral contraceptives.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (Option B): Malignant tumor; often shows hemorrhage, necrosis, no central scar.

Hemangioma (Option D): Cavernous vascular lesion, red-blue on cut section, no central scar.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with history of multiple sexual partners presented with anorexia and jaundice. The biopsy shows ground-glass opacity in the cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hepatitis B

  • This clinical scenario of a male with a promiscuous sexual history and ground-glass opacities on biopsy points to Hepatitis B infection.
  • In chronic Hepatitis B infection, hepatocytes can appear pale and finely granular on histology, called ground-glass hepatocytes.
  • This appearance is due to the accumulation of Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) within the endoplasmic reticulum of infected hepatocytes.
  • Common in chronic carriers and chronic hepatitis B patients.
  • Risk factor- Multiple sexual partners, high risk of sexually transmitted infections, including HBV.

Hepatitis A (Option A):

  • Feco–oral transmission (contaminated food/water), not sexually transmitted in most cases.
  • Does not produce ground-glass hepatocytes.
  • Histology: hepatocyte ballooning degeneration, Councilman bodies in acute hepatitis.

Hepatitis C (Option C):

  • Transmitted mainly via blood (IV drug use, transfusions).
  • Histology shows lymphoid aggregates in portal tracts, steatosis, and no ground-glass appearance.

Hepatitis D (Option D: Histology changes depend on concurrent HBV changes; ground-glass cells still come from the HBV component.)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of liver failure ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B.

  • Paracetamol: Paracetamol overdose is the most common cause of acute liver failure, particularly in cases of intentional or accidental overdose. Paracetamol is metabolized in the liver, and high doses or overdose can overwhelm the liver's detoxification mechanisms, leading to liver damage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Alcohol: While alcohol abuse can lead to liver damage and cirrhosis, it is not the most common cause of acute liver failure. Chronic alcohol abuse can contribute to liver diseases such as alcoholic hepatitis and alcoholic cirrhosis.

Option C. CCI4 (carbon tetrachloride): CCI4 is a toxic chemical that was historically used as a solvent and industrial agent. Exposure to CCI4 can cause severe liver damage and hepatotoxicity, but it is not the most common cause of liver failure.

Option D. Pesticides: Pesticides can have hepatotoxic effects and contribute to liver damage in certain circumstances, such as occupational exposure or accidental ingestion. However, they are not the most common cause of liver failure.

questions.text: Macrophages play an important role in phagocytosis and chronic inflammation. Which of the following cells perform the same function in the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Kupffer cells

Explanation:

  • Kupffer cells are specialised macrophages located within the liver sinusoids.
  • They play a crucial role in phagocytosis, removing pathogens, damaged cells, and cellular debris from the bloodstream.
  • They are also involved in the regulation of immune responses and the promotion of chronic inflammation when necessary.
  • Therefore, Kupffer cells in the liver perform similar functions to macrophages, including phagocytosis and participation in chronic inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Hepatocytes (Option A) are the main functional cells of the liver responsible for various metabolic functions, such as detoxification, synthesis of proteins, and storage of nutrients. While hepatocytes are involved in many liver functions, they do not primarily perform phagocytosis and chronic inflammation.

Merkel cells (Option B) are specialised cells found in the skin and are involved in the sensation of touch and tactile discrimination. They are not present in the liver or involved in phagocytosis or chronic inflammation.

Sinusoidal cells (Option C) refer to the cells lining the sinusoids in the liver, which are specialised blood vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with hepatic angiosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Arsenic

Explanation:

  • Arsenic is a well-established carcinogen for hepatic angiosarcoma.
  • Chronic arsenic exposure leads to DNA damage and promotes endothelial cell malignancy.
  • It also notes that vinyl chloride, Thorotrast, and arsenic are the most frequently implicated agents in hepatic angiosarcoma development.

 

Incorrect Options:

Iron (Option A) overload (e.g., in hereditary hemochromatosis) is primarily associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), not hepatic angiosarcoma.

Copper (Option B) accumulation in Wilson's disease is linked to hepatocyte damage and cirrhosis but is not associated with angiosarcoma development.

Zinc (Option C) is essential for normal cellular function and is not carcinogenic.

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presented to you. The gross appearance of his liver is shown below. Which of the following is true about it?

choices.text: Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver
Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver

 

Explanation:

The scenario of Cirrhosis and ascites, along with the image, shows dark areas indicating necrosis and white areas representing viable liver tissue.

  • It is a chronic liver disease characterized by fibrosis and nodular regeneration of the liver parenchyma.
  • Causes: Chronic alcohol abuse, viral hepatitis, or metabolic disorders.
  • Pathogenesis:
  • Morphology: The liver undergoes significant remodelling, destroying its normal architecture and the formation of fibrous bands. The dark areas indicate necrosis (cellular damage and blood congestion), while the white areas represent viable liver tissue with functional hepatocytes.  (Option B, C, and D ruled out)

 

  • Microscopy: Thick bands of collagen separate rounded cirrhotic nodules (Masson's trichrome stain is commonly used to visualise collagen fibres).

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presents with lower back pain and fever. During history-taking, he mentions experiencing similar episodes in the past with amylase levels being elevated. Which type of necrosis is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fat necrosis

Explanation:

  • The symptoms of lower back pain, fever, recurrent episodes, and elevated amylase levels suggest Pancreatitis, which is associated with fat necrosis.
  • It is divided into two forms, acute and chronic, both of which are initiated by injuries that lead to autodigestion of the pancreas by its own enzymes.
  • Histopathological examination:
    • Gross: Fat and parenchymal necrosis with saponification.

  • Microscopic: Interstitial inflammation, edema, fat necrosis, vessel wall damage, and haemorrhage.

Fibrinoid necrosis (Option A) is associated with antigen-antibody reactions (immune complex deposition).

  • Some examples are:
    • Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN)
    • Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) shows Aschoff Bodies.
    • SLE
    • Malignant Hypertension (HTN)

Coagulative necrosis (Option C) is characteristic of solid organs such as the kidney, liver, and heart (most common). It typically occurs due to ischemic infarction, leading to the preservation of tissue architecture despite cell death. Infarcts in these organs are often wedge-shaped, reflecting the vascular supply pattern.

Liquefaction necrosis (Option D) occurs in tissues rich in hydrolytic enzymes, leading to loss of structural integrity. Also known as colliquative necrosis, it results in complete tissue disintegration without preserved architecture.

questions.text: What is the gene mutation seen in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HFE

Explanation:

  • Hereditary hemochromatosis is due to an HFE gene mutation on chromosome 6p that causes excess iron absorption, leading to increased iron deposition. This results in the classic triad of cirrhosis, secondary diabetes mellitus, and bronze skin.

Hereditary Hemochromatosis:

  • Laboratory findings: High ferritin, high serum iron and low TIBC.
  • Liver biopsy: Golden-yellow hemosiderin granules in periportal hepatocytes that appear blue with a Prussian blue stain followed by a micronodular pattern of cirrhosis.
  • Other findings: dilated cardiomyopathy (M/C cardiac manifestation).
  • Increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma
  • In Hemochromatosis, skin colour changes due to the deposition of excessive melanin >> iron in the skin.
  • It is also known as "bronze diabetes" due to skin discolouration and associated pancreatic disease & typically manifests after 20 g of stored iron has accumulated in the body.

Organs affected

Clinical features

Liver

Hepatomegaly, elevated liver enzymes, risk of HCC

Pancreas

Iron-induced damage of beta cells - diabetes mellitus

Heart

Cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, congestive heart failure

Skin

Hyperpigmentation (bronze skin due to melanin and iron deposition)

Joints

Arthropathy and joint pain

CNS

Rarely - Memory issues, depression and fatigue

Hemochromatosis is of two types:

Types of hemochromatosis

Features

Hereditary hemochromatosis

  • HFE-related: It is the classic form of hereditary hemochromatosis that is inherited in an autosomal recessive (chromosome 6p)
  • HAMP gene mutation-related
  • HJV gene mutation (juvenile hemochromatosis

Acquired/secondary hemochromatosis

  • Repeated blood transfusion
  • Excessive oral intake or iron

 

PTEN (Option B) is a tumour suppressor gene linked to certain cancers and is not associated with hemochromatosis.

ATP7B gene (Option C) mutations cause Wilson's disease, which involves copper accumulation, not iron overload, as in hemochromatosis.

MRP2 protein (Option D) is involved in bile excretion and is related to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, not hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A patient suffering from cholelithiasis underwent cholecystectomy. The image of the specimen is shown below. Which of the following is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image shows a characteristic finding of a gallbladder polyp, which typically presents as a raised, pedunculated lesion on the gallbladder mucosa.
  • They are often benign and can be composed of cholesterol, adenomas, or inflammatory tissue.
  • Gall bladder polyp is a pre-malignant condition presenting with cholecystitis & biliary colic.
  • Types
    • Cholesterol polyp (More common)
    • Adenomatous polyp (Has malignant potential)
  • Risk factors for malignancy in adenomatous polyp:
  • Coexistence of gallstones
  • Age > 60 years
  • Increase in size
  • Size > 10 mm

 

Cholesterolosis (Option A): Often referred to as "strawberry gallbladder" (Option C), it occurs when cholesterol deposits accumulate in the gallbladder wall, giving it a speckled, yellowish appearance.



 

Adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder (Option C) is the most common form of gallbladder cancer, arising from glandular cells and often associated with chronic cholecystitis, gallstones, and older age.

  • It is more common in women.
  • Early stages are usually asymptomatic, but as the tumour progresses, symptoms like right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and weight loss may occur.
  • HER2/neu overexpression and elevated CA 19-9 levels can aid in diagnosis and prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following cells plays a key role in phagocytosis and chronic inflammation in the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Kupffer cells

Explanation:

  • Kupffer cells are specialised macrophages found in sinusoids of the liver and play a key role in phagocytosis and chronic inflammation.
  • They are responsible for clearing pathogens, debris, and old red blood cells from the blood as it passes through the liver.


Incorrect Options:

Hepatocytes (Option A) are vital liver cells responsible for various metabolic functions but are not directly responsible for phagocytosis.

Ito cells (Option B), also called Hepatic stellate cells, are pericytes located in the space of Disse, between hepatocytes and sinusoidal endothelial cells in the liver that store vitamin A and regulate sinusoidal blood flow. Upon liver injury, they activate into myofibroblast-like cells, releasing TGFβ and promoting fibrosis through excessive collagen production.

Sinusoidal endothelial cells (Option C) line the liver's sinusoids and facilitate material exchange between blood and liver cells. While they are not primarily involved in phagocytosis, their unique fenestrated structure enables them to filter blood and regulate molecule movement.

questions.text: Which indicator is best for identifying alcohol disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) GGT

Explanation:

  • Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) is a liver enzyme that is considered a best indicator for alcohol-related liver disease.
  • It is a liver enzyme that is primarily involved in the metabolism of glutathione, an antioxidant, and plays a role in detoxifying substances in the liver.
  • Chronic alcohol consumption can induce liver stress and damage, leading to elevated GGT levels.
  • While it is elevated in alcohol use, its elevation can also occur in several other conditions. Therefore, it is a non-specific marker of alcohol-induced liver damage.

Alcoholic liver disease LFT

AST/ SGOT

(Option B ruled out)
  • Non-specific ; ↑ (<300-400)
  • This is a liver enzyme that rises in conditions causing liver damage, including alcohol-induced liver injury, but it is also elevated in a variety of non-liver conditions, like muscle injury or cardiac events.

ALT/ SGPT

(Option A ruled out)
  • Specific for liver injury ; ↑ (<300-400)
  • This is another liver enzyme that primarily indicates liver cell injury, but it is less specific for alcohol-related liver disease compared to GGT.

AST/ALT ratio: ≥ 2: 1

Specific for ALD

ALP (Alkaline phosphatase)

Elevated in bile duct pathologies

GGT (γ-glutamyl transferase)

Non-specific marker of ALD

5’-Nucleotidase

Specific marker for bile duct pathologies

S.Bilirubin

(Option D ruled out)

Usually normal/mildly ↑

S.Albumin

↓ in chronic liver disease (cirrhosis)

Carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT)

Best serum marker for alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text:
What is the most likely diagnosis for a 25-year-old male who presented with fever and has the following viral marker results:

HBsAg: Positive and IgM anti-HBc antibody: Positive
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute hepatitis:

  • HBsAg is the surface antigen of the Hepatitis B virus and indicates current infection.
  • IgM anti-HBc antibodies are specific to acute infection and indicate recent exposure to the virus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chronic hepatitis: Chronic hepatitis B is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg for more than six months. The presence of IgM anti-HBc antibody indicates an acute or recent infection, making chronic hepatitis less likely.

Option C - Window period: The window period refers to the time between infection and the appearance of detectable markers. In this context, the presence of both HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc antibody suggests an active infection rather than a window period.

Option D - Persistent infection: Persistent infection could be considered for cases with prolonged presence of HBsAg, but the presence of IgM anti-HBc antibody indicates an ongoing immune response, which is more consistent with acute infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, edema, and ascites. On examination, his liver function tests are severely deranged. Further investigation reveals a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma. The pathogenesis of this condition is most likely related to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Aflatoxin:

  • Aflatoxin is a potent carcinogenic toxin produced by certain molds, primarily Aspergillus species. It is a well-known risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma, particularly in individuals with chronic liver disease. Aflatoxin contamination of food, such as grains, nuts, and legumes, can lead to long-term exposure and increase the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Benzol (Benzene): Benzene is a chemical compound found in various industrial processes. Exposure to high levels of benzene is associated with the risk of developing leukemia, particularly acute myeloid leukemia. However, benzene exposure is not a known cause of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option B - Arsenic: Arsenic exposure has been linked to various health issues, including skin lesions, cardiovascular disease, and certain types of cancer (such as skin, lung, and bladder cancer). While arsenic exposure might contribute to liver damage in chronic exposures, it is not a primary cause of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option D - Vinyl Chloride: Vinyl chloride is a chemical used in the production of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) plastic and has been associated with liver damage, including a rare form of angiosarcoma known as hepatic angiosarcoma. However, this type of cancer is relatively rare, and hepatocellular carcinoma is not directly linked to vinyl chloride exposure

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dubin-Johnson syndrome

Explanation:

  • Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It is characterised by impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile due to a defect in the MRP2 transporter, leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Darkly pigmented liver (accumulation of epinephrine metabolite).

questions.text: A health care worker has been found to be seropositive for HBsAg, HBeAg, and anti-HBc IgM, indicating an acute HBV infection with high infectivity. A liver biopsy in such cases is likely to show all the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ground glass hepatocytes:

  • Ground glass hepatocytes are hepatocytes with a granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm. This appearance is due to the accumulation of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) within the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes.
  • This feature is more characteristic of chronic HBV infection rather than acute infection. It reflects ongoing viral replication and chronicity.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D 

  • A. Ballooning change of hepatocytes: Common in acute hepatitis.
  • C. Focal or spotty necrosis: Common in acute hepatitis.
  • D. Confluent necrosis of hepatocytes: Seen in severe acute hepatitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of having dark tan skin despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. What is this patient most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hemochromatosis:

  • The patient's presentation with dark tan skin and histopathological findings showing iron deposition in liver cells is suggestive of hemochromatosis.
  • Hemochromatosis is a hereditary disorder characterized by the accumulation of iron in the body, which can lead to damage to various organs, including the liver, heart, and pancreas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Wilson's disease:

  • Wilson's disease is an inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in various organs, including the liver, brain, and eyes.
  • The symptoms of Wilson's disease usually begin in childhood or early adulthood and can include neurological symptoms such as tremors, dystonia, and difficulty with coordination.
  • The liver damage associated with Wilson's disease can lead to hepatomegaly, as well as signs of liver disease such as jaundice, ascites, and elevated liver enzymes.

Option B - Autoimmune hepatitis:

  • Autoimmune hepatitis is a chronic autoimmune disorder that causes inflammation and damage to the liver.
  • The symptoms of autoimmune hepatitis can include fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes, and abdominal pain.
  • Liver damage can lead to hepatomegaly, as well as signs of liver disease such as jaundice, ascites, and elevated liver enzymes.

Option C - α-1 antitrypsin deficiency:

  • α-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that affects the production of a protein called α-1 antitrypsin, which plays a role in protecting the lungs and liver from damage.
  • The symptoms of α-1 antitrypsin deficiency can include respiratory symptoms such as shortness of breath and coughing, as well as liver diseases such as hepatomegaly and elevated liver enzymes.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the patient with the following serological status: HbsAg positive and HbeAg positive?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acute viral hepatitis with infectivity:

  • HbsAg is the earliest and most reliable marker of HBV infection.
  • HbeAg is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity.
  • The serological status of HbsAg positive and HbeAg positive indicates an acute hepatitis B infection with infectivity.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Chronic viral hepatitis is seen with all of the following viruses, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - HEV:

  • The hepatitis E virus causes an acute self-limiting infection.
  • HEV is mainly transmitted through the fecal-oral route and is commonly associated with acute hepatitis.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C can lead to chronic hepatitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of a dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from which condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hemochromatosis:

  • Hemochromatosis is a genetic disorder characterized by excessive iron absorption and accumulation in various organs, including the liver.
  • Hepatomegaly is a common finding in hemochromatosis due to iron deposition in hepatocytes.
  • The liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron staining supports the diagnosis of hemochromatosis in this patient.
  • Darkening of the skin, known as bronze diabetes or dark tan, is another characteristic feature of hemochromatosis resulting from iron deposition in the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Wilson's disease:

  • Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterized by impaired copper transport, leading to copper accumulation in various organs, including the liver and brain.
  • It typically presents with hepatic and neurological symptoms, such as hepatomegaly, jaundice, and neurologic manifestations.

Option B - Autoimmune hepatitis:

  • Autoimmune hepatitis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by immune-mediated inflammation of the liver.
  • It can present with hepatomegaly, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes.

Option C - Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to liver and lung diseases.
  • Liver involvement in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency typically presents as neonatal cholestasis or later-onset liver disease.

questions.text: All of these are characteristic features of pancreatic carcinoma, except:

choices.text: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
Carcinoma of body pancreas often present with jaundice

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Carcinoma of body pancreas often present with jaundice:

  • Carcinomas of the body and tail of the pancreas often do not present with jaundice because they are not located near the common bile duct.
  • Jaundice is more commonly associated with tumors located in the head of the pancreas, where they can obstruct the common bile duct and lead to the accumulation of bilirubin in the bloodstream.
  • In contrast, tumors in the body of the pancreas may cause symptoms such as abdominal pain, weight loss, and digestive issues but are less likely to cause jaundice.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cigarette smoking is a risk factor:

  • Cigarette smoking is a well-established risk factor for pancreatic carcinoma.
  • It is one of the most significant environmental risk factors for developing pancreatic cancer, increasing the likelihood of developing the disease.

Option C - They elicit intense desmoplastic response:

  • Pancreatic carcinoma is known for its intense desmoplastic response.
  • The tumor microenvironment in pancreatic cancer is characterized by the proliferation of fibrous connective tissue, which creates a dense stromal reaction around the tumor cells.
  • This desmoplastic response contributes to the poor prognosis and therapeutic challenges associated with pancreatic carcinoma.

Option D - Perineural invasion is common:

  • Perineural invasion is a common feature of pancreatic carcinoma.
  • The tumor cells have a propensity to invade and infiltrate along the nerves in the vicinity of the pancreas, which can contribute to the spread and metastasis of the disease.
